elements.text: Does anyone have any tips for organising backtest results? The output of my backtests is one file per event so each backtest occupies a single directory. I'm currently distinguishing between the different parameters used in each backtest in the directory name but this is quickly becoming unwieldy as I add more parameters and it's hardly the best way to encode this information. For example:
.../backtests/results-new-min-roi-0.0-max-roi-120.0-max-price-1000-bankroll-10000-bet-latency-100ms-cooldown-20000ms-entire-race-with-tags
I'm thinking of having some kind of "meta file" in each backtest directory that could contain these parameters and other useful information for example:

and/or possibly have a top-level index of the backtests, either in a flat file or SQLite database and then the directories can have uninformative names like "00000043" or "cc097b8048064a3acd969de313e52f9b3fd896c7"

text: How about storing the parameters in DynamoDB, and linking to an S3 location containing the backtest results? That allows evolution of variety for the parameters and metrics, queryable backtest results and relatively low setup/maintenance effort.

elements.text: How about storing the parameters in DynamoDB, and linking to an S3 location containing the backtest results? That allows evolution of variety for the parameters and metrics, queryable backtest results and relatively low setup/maintenance effort.

text: SQL would be my choice. Easy to write during the backtest and quick to search / analyse when you want to revisit ideas. One table for backtests and parms with any other output info you want. Maybe even child tables depending on your test outputs. Call sql at start of test to create new entry and give you a unique id key for the backtest which becomes the folder name ?

elements.text: SQL would be my choice. Easy to write during the backtest and quick to search / analyse when you want to revisit ideas. One table for backtests and parms with any other output info you want. Maybe even child tables depending on your test outputs. Call sql at start of test to create new entry and give you a unique id key for the backtest which becomes the folder name ?

text:
since i also do local backtesting, i went like this:
• add a json file with the git commit and the exact command line i used, plus the parameters in abstract form.
• add a line in a psql database which contains exactly the json file contents +  directory
• group backtests by "idea"", which are named by the directory
• still name the directory of each iteration of the tuning grid with a reasonablel fantasy name (edit: prefix), this is to avoid duplication and still have a way to remember which thing is which at a glance (so something like, big-horses-roi4)
psql or sqlite up to you, but psql was easy because i already had it and i can add json querying. the json file is because i may want to process things with the json file on another machine without having to port the psql over.

elements.text: since i also do local backtesting, i went like this:
add a json file with the git commit and the exact command line i used, plus the parameters in abstract form.
add a line in a psql database which contains exactly the json file contents +  directory
group backtests by "idea"", which are named by the directory

still name the directory of each iteration of the tuning grid with a reasonablel fantasy name (edit: prefix), this is to avoid duplication and still have a way to remember which thing is which at a glance (so something like, big-horses-roi4)

psql or sqlite up to you, but psql was easy because i already had it and i can add json querying. the json file is because i may want to process things with the json file on another machine without having to port the psql over.

text: Thanks for the input <@URMM9463X>. My immediate reaction is cloud services are overkill for this but I'll mull it over

text: <@U01C12ZEADQ> have you considered just having a “label” column/field that could contain the “big-horses-roi4” description?

elements.text: have you considered just having a “label” column/field that could contain the “big-horses-roi4” description?

text: i think it's a bit of short term vs long term: if i am working on something my mind is fresh, so directory names are cheap and easy enough and very fast to glance over. I don't expect it to be fully descriptive though, that's why the params file. however, i know myself and in 2 months i won't remember which other parameters i. changed or i kept fixed, that's why i save the full command line in the file

elements.text: i think it's a bit of short term vs long term: if i am working on something my mind is fresh, so directory names are cheap and easy enough and very fast to glance over. I don't expect it to be fully descriptive though, that's why the params file. however, i know myself and in 2 months i won't remember which other parameters i. changed or i kept fixed, that's why i save the full command line in the file

text: i still have a 'description' field in the db/file, which is free form

elements.text: i still have a 'description' field in the db/file, which is free form

text: but in general, the uninformative name is completely ok once you are done, but while working on it i prefer to have _some_ info there. it can even ben 'iteration-172' but I find it easy to remember. the double directory structure (idea/tuning-grid-idea) is just easier for cleanup/archival later

text: <@UBS7QANF3> I have a bias towards cloud/serverless over local for most things and find dynamo just really convenient. It might be the lazy option. SQL databases didn't work well for me, was difficult to keep adjusting the structure to match the direction of experiments and variety of parameters as things evolved. <@U01C12ZEADQ>’s point of using psql to store the json makes sense but then I'd have to run a postgres database. Interesting topic!

elements.text: I have a bias towards cloud/serverless over local for most things and find dynamo just really convenient. It might be the lazy option. SQL databases didn't work well for me, was difficult to keep adjusting the structure to match the direction of experiments and variety of parameters as things evolved.
’s point of using psql to store the json makes sense but then I'd have to run a postgres database. Interesting topic!

text: dynamodb for a single-user, single-task, write-once -read-many looks really overkill tbh, sqlite can do json as well and it's a file

elements.text: dynamodb for a single-user, single-task, write-once -read-many looks really overkill tbh, sqlite can do json as well and it's a file

text: the only real advantage is that you can access it from everywhere, imho

elements.text: the only real advantage is that you can access it from everywhere, imho

text: <@U01C12ZEADQ> - agreed, and sqlite is great. Access from everywhere can be useful. For my similar but different use case, I needed to read and update params from one or more ec2.

elements.text: - agreed, and sqlite is great. Access from everywhere can be useful. For my similar but different use case, I needed to read and update params from one or more ec2.

text: Minor point but I should add that I output all of this stuff to a directory in my Dropbox so it is technically available from anywhere although perhaps not quite as frictionless as AWS

text: Been thinking about this as well recently - a half-baked idea I had was to try using <https://github.com/mlflow/mlflow|mlflow>. It's designed for a very similar situation where you’re training hundreds or thousands of ML models, all with different parameters, and need a flexible way to attach performance metrics to each run. Definitely might be overkill though..

attachments.text: Open source platform for the machine learning lifecycle
attachments.title: mlflow/mlflow
